fields.project_brief: This is a pilot project to run and evaluate a land-based language camp to provide accessible cultural support to the Aboriginal Street Community.
The project documents historical Nuuchahnulth tapes with a transcriber and team of Elder translators.

This is a project to edit and share language resources through the school's website to make Secwepemctsin language resources available to community members.  The project also includes developing a proficiency framework to provide criteria for evaluating existing learning resources.

fields.community_affiliation: Blueberry River First Nations;Doig River First Nation;Fort Nelson First Nation;Halfway River First Nation;Prophet River First Nation
fields.project_brief: This traditional and cultural programming project brings together youth, Elders, parents and community members to learn Dane-Ẕaa through classroom teachings, group teachings, an annual youth and Elders Gathering camp, and the youth-led development of a Dane-Ẕaa bingo game.
Yun Wha ootle Wakunkec Program is a three year language program to revitalization the Dakelh/Wetswuten Language.

This curriculum development project builds upon the successes of previous project phases by continuing the development of sequential intermediate Łingít language materials and teaching methods, based on original Elder recordings.

fields.community_affiliation: Aitchelitz Band;Cheam First Nation;Katzie First Nation;Kwantlen First Nation;Kwaw-kwaw-aplit First Nation;Matsqui First Nation;Peters Band;Shxw’owhamel First Nation;Shxwhá:y Village;Skowkale First Nation;Skwah First Nation;Soowahlie Indian Band;Tzeachten First Nation
fields.project_brief: This is a documentation and digitization project to archive over 500 Halq'eméylem language audio cassette recordings.

The 3-year project is to implement a sequential Hul'q'umi'num' immersion program starting at the Lelum'uy'lh Daycare Centre in a junior kindergarten class, then continuing at Quwùtsun Smuneem in the Kindergarten class and then the grade 1 class.  The program services a cohort through 3 years of curriculum implementation.

The project develops textbooks and lessons for beginner Ditidaht learners, available in electronic format, along with Ditidaht story books and comic books. These resources will be used in Ditidaht Community School language classes and adult learning classes, and accessible to members off-reserve.
This is a project to create a comprehensive language plan to revitalize Dane-Ẕaa and celebrate the language, stories, and traditions of Doig River First Nation in all facets of the community.
This three-year project creates new speakers over three years with 300 hrs of immersion per year. Students are heads of families, some with children.

fields.community_affiliation: Lower Similkameen Indian Band;Osoyoos Indian Band;Westbank First Nation
fields.project_brief: This project involves immersion-style language discussions between the high language fluent speakers in each of seven nsyilxcn communities with intermediate fluent speakers, listening and learning to participate in the conversation in a comfortable everyday way.

This traditional and cultural language programming project engages community members in Secwepemctsin language learning through language immersion sessions, cultural activities, and online and written resources.

This project combines immersion programming, traditional and cultural language programming, documentation and recording, and materials development to increase Gitsanimx̱ language learning, improve fluency, and share traditional knowledge, especially for youth in the community.

fields.recipient: Gitmaxmak'ay Nisga'a Prince Rupert / Port Edward Society
fields.project_brief: The project increases the number of conversational Nisga'a speakers in the local communities of Prince Rupert and Port Edward by connecting participants with fluent Nisga'a Elder speakers from their traditional territory.
This is a curriculum development project for a Gitsenimx̱ language adult immersion program to promote intermediate speaking proficiency.

The project focuses on adult language acquisition for Gitxaala citizens in both the village of Lach Klan and in Prince Rupert.  Sm'algyax videos profiling key sites throughout Gitxaala territory are filmed with direct participation of adult learners.  Language classes are offered at the Continuous Learning Centre.
This project implements the Gitxsanimx language into the draft framework of the Gitxsan Traditional Parenting Material for the program.
This is a Haida language Mentor-Apprentice project.
This traditional and cultural language programming project promotes and preserves Gitga'at language and traditions through Sm’algya̱x teaching sessions, cultural visits, and experiential learning.
This project is to develop a five-year strategic plan for Haíɫzaqvḷa revitalization, establish a language authority board, and hire a full-time coordinator for the process.

Four mentors create four new speakers who are young adults of working age.  The two people who have completed FPCC's 3-year MAP train the four new MAP teams, offering additional support and learning materials that are specifically targeted at the language.
This project continues Homalco's First Voices project, recording and uploading new Éy7á7juuthem words and phrases to the site.

Indigenous arts vitality research across the province of BC and support for the Indigenous Music Retreat
To showcase art at the International Vancouver Art Fair in April 2020
To share music for communities to have the opportunity to experience the ability of music to empower, heal and make social change.
To record a 10 song solo album at Park Sound Studios with producer Andy Schichter and session drummer Kelly Stodola. Some songs will feature the Nsyilxcn Language.
To create five appliqued women's jackets, as well as five painted leather bags to complete the collection of Northwest Coast fashion I have started.

fields.community_affiliation: Lower Similkameen Indian Band - Okanagan Nation
fields.project_brief: To author, illustrate and record a children's book translated in nsyilxcn based on seasonal activities with both contemporary and culturally relevant activities.
To be mentored by Caroline Lytton, Nicoamen cedar basket weaver, and learn collecting, locating, preparing, and conserving cedar, spruce roots and cherry bark for cedar basket making.
To create one-of-a-kind special edition collection that will showcase my artistic skills and formline of my culture. It will consist of a bracelet, a pendant and earrings.
To create five large scale multimedia pieces that incorporate Métis beading techniques for a solo art show, which will be completed in seven months.
To support travel to compete in Memphis in January 2020, and to New Orleans to participate in the International Indigenous Music Summit at Folk Alliance (Jan. 2020)

To create an experimental documentary of life as a Private Statement Gatherer highlighting my extraordinary experiences with video footage and original artwork, while trying to answer the question of reconciliation.
To track, mix, master, and release my debut solo album which combines modern rock music with my traditional fiddling upbringing.
Ms. PAN!K - Artist development Program Support and Marketing/Promo Video 2019/2020.
To create a collection of cedar woven regalia based upon the regalia of my Quw'utsun' and Snuneymuxw Ancestors, and study other fibres used within said regalia
To research Kwakwaka'wakw culture, history and spirituality along with a writing retreat to contribute to the completion of the final installments of the Overhead series "Trees"
To record, mix, and master songs to complete an album. This project will include vocal, songwriting, and performance coaching for release and related performances
To pursue new techniques and devote full attention to creating work.
To dedicate my full time to improve skills, gain more experience, and create work independently as a music producer and engineer.
To be mentored in the unique Métis art form of whitefish scale art with Jaime Morse.
To undertake a series of artistic development initiatives. This project will involve travel, sound recording, music and video production and digital marketing.
To improve skills in photography/inventory artwork
To support two paintings about Syilx Captikwl.

To support a beaded-watercolour landscapes mentorship: Introducing our people, languages, and 'traditional' plants in a contemporary context. Working with local, Northwest Coast and Métis artists holders to learn, produce and show a new style of Métis art
To cast, direct, rehearse, create choreography, and then produce the world premiere for the interdisciplinary stage play, So Damn Proud.

To attend a carving with hard stone (jade) course with one of the best jade carvers in the world, Deborah Wilson. Starting in February I will start my jade sculpture of the thunderbird carrying the whale away based on a Coast Salish legend.
To create a 6-8 track sound recording that demonstrates a deepening awareness, an enriched community, Indigenous collaboration and artistic development.
To devote more time to harvest natural materials to make more traditional baskets and organize photos and promotional materials to develop an educational and marketing plan.
To carve a red cedar panel depicting the past, present, and future of Nuxalkmc people. The panel will be displayed at the newly constructed Nuxalk Acwsacmalslayc Academy of Learning Office
To complete my second CD, support studio time to record, and mixing and mastering. To support an album cover, purchase beats, and put together promotional material.
To further develop my craft through mentorship with the medicine wheel as my guide and bring awareness to postpartum depression.
To cover costs to complete original CD "RED EARTH" for Sandy Scofield
To share my Tsilhqot'in language and culture through clothing, and also to raise awareness about our murdered and missing Indigenous people
To create a complete solo art show: new mixed media drawings and sculptural forms featuring handmade objects with words/phrases in both English and Denésuliné
To create a hip-hop album by working with professionals in the music industry and promote it at a professional level
To explore and test production of a new form of Salish blankets with an aim to decolonize and indigenize the machine production of our blankets.
To record an EP of original singer-songwriter music at Cedar Mountain Studios in Vancouver from February To April 2020.
To create and raise an Alhkw'alhtnak (landmark) near one of our ancestral village sites.
To create Who We Walk With/Who We Stand With, which represents a modern Haida Elder and Coast Salish Elder creating together
To conduct research and experiment with projection mapping technology on large scale drawings
To record my first LP (full length) album with record producer, Winston Hauschild at Hipposonic Studios in Vancouver with professional session musicians.
To create a series of complex, abstract expressionist beaded art pieces that explore memories, with accompanying written pieces that include learning Haislakala language.
To construct two Kwakwaka'wakw-style cedar bentwood boxes under the mentorship of Bruce Alfred

To continue to teach beginner painting classes in First Nations communities, providing all the supplies needed including canvas, easels, paint brushes + paint. Classes will be at no cost to communities
To record and produce my sophomore album, tying my First Nations roots in with my modern work, showcasing Métis creativity and identity

To create 'This Land is Your Land This Land is My Land This Land Was First Nations Land - a revision of the 1944 Woody Guthrie song illustrated using a pre-contact, pre-colonial map of Nations in the area that is now Canada. To be an illustrated book
To support hunting and hide harvest, hosting a 1.5 week long Hide Harvest from start to finish.
To create a radio/podcast audio series documenting traditional skills shared in fine detail, through thoughtful artist interviews, their Elder guides and use of creative soundscapes.
To support three mentor workshops (storytelling, carving and painting) to enable youth to learn traditional arts in a contemporary form and create their own art.

To send three traditional artists to provide teachings at the "Hills are Alive" - Metis Culture, Music and Dance festival in Cypress Hills Alberta in June 2020. Provide two drum and drumstick making workshops, drumming activities and drum song sharing for fifteen Boundary Aboriginal youth, as well as ten participants from the Metis festival.
To write a guide for building steaming boxes based on testing prototypes and teach 6 students bentwood box carving.

fields.project_brief: To support a Nuu-chah-nulth women's language and culture sharing group culminating in a canoe journey through the Nuu-chah-nulth communities.

To transfer knowledge across generations using Sm'algyax art in exchanges between Kitsumkalum artist, Sm'algyax language champions, Elders and students of Na'aksa Gilak 'yoo school and community.

To support a series of regional traditional workshops To support the learning of protocols associated with working within traditional arts materials with Elders, artists, and traditional knowledge keepers.
A Bakwamkala story-writing workshop with Gwa'sala 'Nakwaxda'xw youth and Elders, led by 'Nakwaxda'xw Writer and Language Revitalization Coordinator, Lucy Hemphill.
To support the creation of contemporary song connecting us To earth in respect and responsibility with accompanying dance, regalia and book To use in language nest.
To give myself the opportunity To showcase the importance of an indigenous woman, sharing the stories of my peoples through carving.
To provide workshops that teach skills based on the land and what is ready to be harvested.
To support Kitsumkalum with on the land experiences for language and cultural revitalization with community members, elders, and youth - strengthening our identity as Tsimshian.
To support bringing artists and youth together To plan and create a totem pole, focusing on culture, protocols and the local Kwakiutl traditions and Kwak̓wala language.
To strengthen the embodied artistic practice of traditional Indigenous tattooing in the Interior of BC through mentorship and training in skin stich and hand poke tattooing techniques.
To learn To jingle dress dance and To make my regalia for dancing.
To support to traditional woodcarving with Joe Martin where participants will work on and proudly take home either a paddle or bentwood box.
To create a large scale feast dish in the community with lead artist Gilbert Dawson, associate artist Marianne Nicolson and an apprentice artist.

To support the students at Outma Sqilx’w Cultural School create a large-scale textile mural depicting images related to the Syilx Nation Siwɬkw Declaration, their personal family histories related To Siwɬkw and traditional social dances, led by artist/mentor Catherine Pierre.
To teach Nuchaanulth style basketry, gather material and complete a basket.
To teach St'at'imx Nation citizens traditional dances and songs to the communities along the In-SHUCK-ch FSR.
To create a project called Urban Pow Wow Youth Project, a gathering of young Indigenous dancers who would like to further their knowledge and understanding of Pow Wow dance.
To strengthen my abilities and knowledge of Chilkat weaving and joinery techniques by weaving a dance apron during a mentorship with Chilkat weavers.
To support public art work on BC hydro box and posts using graffiti proof wrap. Located in front of Jackson High School with a traditional garden planted around.

To support teaching how to do traditional work with First Nations art to 350 people through 35 workshops at Kermode Friendship Society.

fields.project_brief: To host an Indigenous Art Exhibit highlighting Indigenous youth photographers in Victoria and Vancouver.
To complete Nisga'a playwright Larry Guno's script, "Bunk #7" with a living writer, and train emerging Indigenous actors for a full-scale northwest BC tour in May 2020.
To support the TteS Cultural Experience Strategic Plan project to use community and partnership engagement to identify the priorities, goals and initiatives of the SMHP over the next five years.

To build capacity, knowledge, skills, through tradition and Elders artistic cultural preservation, training Haida Ambassadors/Youth with Totem Poles. Language and knowledge in Old Masset on Haida Gwaii.
To intern at the Cowichan Valley Museum and Archives, focusing on photographs, past and future, curating materials leading to exhibit in 2021.
To assist with providing an internship To Nimkish O'Sullivan-Younging in the areas of artistic programming, community engagement, music curation, social media marketing, event coordination and more.
Shaleyea will join KAC team in a supportive role in planning and marketing existing events, and take full ownership of one new art exhibit.
The intern will teach her craft for 3 months, assist with all cultural activities and create a database of local artists, venues and galleries.
To provide intern Lindsey Willie with administrative skills development over the course of an 11 month distance mentorship with Lou-Ann Neel for Nunwakola Cultural Society

To support a multi-disciplinary event series using art and intergenerational collaboration building a platform for two-spirit community/knowledge building, developing best practices for ethical presentation of two-spirit stories.
Intern Zoe will take part in an artistic/administrative internship with Spotted Fawn Productions where mentor Amanda Strong will help her gain vital skillsets in many areas of production.

fields.community_affiliation: Coast Salish, Cowichan Tribes, Comiaken Nation
fields.project_brief: To support me when I will be a member of an Indigenous Artist Team which will mentor/direct Indigenous individuals and groups for a production called Vision Quest, which will be performed at the Belfry Theatre in Victoria B.C. May 2020.
To purchase supplies and to prepare for my second solo art exhibition.
To attend Indigenous Aesthetics and Community Building Institute as artist in residence in Montreal from May 11 – 30, 2019.
To create a short documentary on the Blueberry Festival and wild blueberry foraging in Fort McMurray through the support of the National Screen Institute's IndigiDocs program.

To accept the invitation to Banff Centre for Arts and Creativity for Indigenous Playwrights Circle, and work with a creative team on the play Beneath the Surface. They will prepare to publish both play and supporting interactive study guide.

fields.community_affiliation: Bush Cree (Big stone Cree Nation) Metis, Metis Nation of BC
fields.project_brief: To attend a screening of The Body Remembers When the World Broke Open at TIFF - a feature film I performed in
To attend the Toronto International Film Festival.
To build 18-24 "Snow Snake" Poles for a new art project to be displayed for the 2020 Arctic Winter Games.
To support the Visible Bodies Collective, an inclusive transient group of Indigenous women who come from many nations and places across Turtle Island, preparing to perform Feb. 1.
To host a graduation ceremony for Native Education Centre's Northwest Coast Jewelry Arts Program at Bill Reid Gallery.
To support my annual 'Pilot Season' in Los Angeles. I pay out of pocket to be seen at casting sessions in the biggest movie studios across California.
To create a contemporary multimedia movement piece telling the story of my journey of discovering and taking ownership of my Two Spirit Metis identity.
To cover short-term living expenses and accommodation during the project "The Racist Guy".
To travel between Vancouver and Hope to work with the story editor for a screenplay.
To perform in New Mexico
To travel to Montreal to showcase my music at the Mundial Montreal which is a springboard for national and international career development.
To support Hey Cuzzin - a comedic look into the antics that Indigenous cousins get into on and off the reserve.
To showcase and conference at Indigenous Music Summit @Folk Alliance, New Orleans, Louisiana - January 20-27, 2020.
To travel to showcase our music at the Kamloops Pow Wow.
To revitalize the tradition of carving in your community by sharing stories, traditional teachings, art, and the Kwakwaka'wakw language at the community carving shed.
To perform at the Indigenous Music West Showcase 2019 in Winnipeg.
To travel from Vancouver to New Louisiana for 7 days to attend and preform at the Indigenous Music Summit.
To design and create personal fancy shawl regalia for pow wow.
To attend the beading symposium: ziigiminishin Winnipeg 2020, February 6-9, to exchange knowledge and build community
To support learning introduction to stone carving and creating sculptures using soft stone.
To add to my existing analog recording studio by purchasing high quality blank 1/4" tape.

fields.community_affiliation: Mohawk, Six Nations of the Grand River
fields.project_brief: To travel to Mundial Montreal to showcase and attend networking sessions with talent buyers from November 19-22, 2019.
To perform in New Mexico
To travel with ANSWER Drumming Group To Port Alberni to train in deep, spiritual practices on the land.
To travel to New Orleans on January 20, 2020 to attend a week-long International Music Summit

To attend the Beadwork Symposium in Feb. 2020 in Winnipeg. The symposium will offer connections to learning and networking for my artistic practice and specifically a collaborative artwork with 2 other Metis artists involving beading and Blood Memory.
To support a networking trip to take classes and watch rehearsals with dance companies in Montreal and Toronto.
To support a performance opportunity at Festival Du Voyageur in Winnipeg, Manitoba.
To assist with creating orchestral scores for orchestras in Ontario and Quebec from pieces that come from traditional Lil'Wat music, or have been influenced by it.
To create the forms for traditional cedar root baskets.
To support Indigenous illuminations in ordering and presenting four Indigenous designed ceiling light vinyl, in eight different colours, for a Victoria Makers Mixer.

fields.community_affiliation: Urban Aboriginal, Carrier, Cree, Metis, Wetseweten
fields.project_brief: To provide free artist workspace and exhibition space. To build two large display cases and modify building into art gallery, Indigenous artist market and exhibition space for Indigenous artists.
To support the Esk'etmc Art Room refurbishment project to encourage participation in the arts by renovating our community art space to create a well-functioning room.

To repair the roof, stairs, and porch of the cabin at Skalula7 - the location of our Kwezan'tsut Camps and to move some electrical components at the Lilwat7ul Culture Centre for the upcoming installation of a permanent weaving and stone tool exhibit.
To focus on building a space so community members of the Tl'etinqox can go and work on deer and fur pelts to dry and tan for trade and sale.
To support Bush Gallery, a land-based Indigenous art gallery that will conduct workshops invested in the relatedness and space for innovation within cedar root basket making and Secwepemc language.

To lease a rental of a building for 2 years for sharing the rich cultural history of the Tseshaht in the Alberni Valley, Alberni Inlet and Central Barkley Sound and allow Tseshaht artists to sell their arts.
Derek will mentor under Kyle Kraft in all aspects of music management and arts administration.
The project will support my music production abilities by supporting the development of my personal album and my ability to produce other local talent
To gain expertise as a music professional, roles including: artist liaison, booking musicians, contract writing, and building artist contact lists.
To receive advanced audio engineering training from Tom Dabrzanski at Monarch Studios in Vancouver. The goal is to improve Scott's ability as a producer, mix engineer and audio engineer.
To develop best engineering practices from Alexis Leycraft, while establishing and operating an independent recording studio to serve the Indigenous Okanagan community
To become proficient in recording and producing culturally religious songs in Kwak̓wala.
To use CFUV's weekly live music sessions (Basement Closet sessions) to get first hand experience working will all kinds of artists and produce an album on tape.
Live IndigiFUNK band Curtis Clear Sky and the Constellationz will tour BC in July 2020 with promotion leading up to the events
To promote and market Nimkish's second album, titled Damage Control

fields.title: Elders' Gifts
fields.project_brief: Create video recordings with Elders demonstrating their gifts to youth.

fields.title: Winter Wellness
fields.project_brief: Sharing cultural activities and wellness teachings with the urban indigenous population to reconnect to heritage and expressions of modern Indigeneity.

fields.title: Moccasin Making
fields.project_brief: Staff and students at the Gitanyow Independent School worked together with the help of Elders to make their own hide moccasins.

fields.title: Trapping Revitalization
fields.project_brief: Revitalizing a trapline to safely bring members out to experience Lheidli Tenneh Nation's cultural heritage.

fields.title: St'at'imc Transformer Sites and Knowledge
fields.project_brief: Provide a series of 10 workshops aimed to share and preserve St'at'imc culture through song and dance.

fields.title: Learning from each other
fields.project_brief: Elders and Knowledge keepers gather and learn from each other and share knowledge about their cultural heritage.

fields.title: We Wai Kai Nation, Village Site Map
fields.project_brief: Mapping out traditional village sites in the Quadra Island and Campbell River aras.

fields.title: Celebrating Song, Stories and Design
fields.project_brief: Hand drum making workshop for Elders and their friends, including a Haida form design painting component.

fields.title: The People of Penelakut
fields.project_brief: Student led research project to document and celebrate Indigenous heritage for the Penelakut Tribe.

fields.title: Seasons of the Moon
fields.project_brief: Researching past life-natural resources in correlation with the seasons by moon.

fields.title: Cheam Nation Longhouse Participation
fields.project_brief: Participation in long house and cultural connection retreat for Indigenous residents in recovery from addictions.

fields.title: Cedar Root, Rush and Pine Needle Basketry
fields.project_brief: Teaching the traditional method of cedar root and rush basket weaving using locally harvested pine needles.

fields.title: Mayaxala - Respect All Things
fields.project_brief: Workshop that focuses on celebrating heritage with youth using traditional Kwakwaka'wakw teachings that will incorporate kwakwala language, traditions and history.

fields.title: Preserving First Nation Heritage and History
fields.project_brief: Record and preserve heritage practices passed down through the years, from one generation to the next, working with Uchucklesaht Tribe Elders.

fields.title: Living Laws: Reconnecting to the Land Through Our Stories
fields.project_brief: Connecting Dene and Cree cultural heritage to the land through stories and drawing knowledge and principles from these stories to help work through today's environmental challenges

fields.title: Gitxaala Heritage Site Research and Documentation Project
fields.project_brief: Complete detailed documentation on Gitxaala heritage sites with multiple outcomes including site management and resilience plans, cumulative effects and climate change mitigation, marine splill response strategies and placename identification.

fields.title: You Can't Manage What You Don't Know: Heiltsuk Tranditional Use and Site Mapping
fields.project_brief: Identification and recording of Heiltsuk cultural heritage sites.

fields.title: Gyaulas - Kwak'wala word for "A Place We Came From"
fields.project_brief: Teach traditional sustainable resource use to youth.

fields.title: The Land and People are Together as One
fields.project_brief: Bringing together Elders, Knowledge Keepers and fluent speakers with Xetolacw community students on the land to explore and document cultural heritage connections.

fields.title: Land and Sea Cultural Project
fields.project_brief: Connect vulnerable Indigenous youth with their traditions and culture by providing them with opportunities to work with Elder and cultural experts.

fields.title: The Supernatural Ones
fields.project_brief: Conduct land based learning and knowledge repatriation programming for the Dzawada'enuxw community.

fields.title: Liglidax Territory Past and Future
fields.project_brief: Document traditional knowledge and resource managmebnt of 10 village sites.

fields.title: Integrating TEK and Nsylixcen language into natural resource management in Sylix Okanagan territory
fields.project_brief: Incorporate natural laws, protocols and language of the syilx Okanagan.

fields.title: Penelakut Tribe Story Trails
fields.project_brief: Caretaking project where children from the Penelakut Elementary School participate in a land-based community program of building a 2.2 km Forest Trail on Penelakut land.

fields.title: Community Knowledge Keeper Capacity
fields.project_brief: Integrate land based cultural and heritage information into the Community Knowledge Keeper program.

fields.title: Seven Generations to Come: N'xukmen and Nt'akmen in Samahquamicw Land Knowledge and Decision Making Practices
fields.project_brief: Facilitate samahquamicw sharings and enhance understandings of the ancestral connections and safeguarding practices between our protocols, metaphors, stories and Samahquamicw territory/environment.

fields.title: The Land, Our Home Around Us
fields.project_brief: Create colouring books that include information about traditional place names, plants and animals while exploring the impact of activity in the region.

fields.title: Williams Lake Indian Band Traditional Place Name Inventory
fields.project_brief: Traditional place name inventory project designed to improve access to traditional Secwepemcs in names for geographic locations of cultural significance to the WLIB.
